statement.p: Let V={\mathbb R}. For u,v \in V and a\in{\mathbb R} define vector addition by u \boxplus v := u+v + 3 and scalar multiplication by a \boxdot u := au + 3a - 3. It can be shown that (V,\boxplus,\boxdot) is a vector space over the scalar field \mathbb R. Find the following:
The sum 5\boxplus -6:
The scalar multiple 8\boxdot 5:
The zero vector, \underline{0}_V:
The additive inverse of x, \boxminus x:

Let V=(-5,\infty). For u,v \in V and a\in{\mathbb R} define vector addition by u \boxplus v := uv + 5(u+v)+20 and scalar multiplication by a \boxdot u := (u + 5)^a - 5. It can be shown that (V,\boxplus,\boxdot) is a vector space over the scalar field \mathbb R. Find the following:
The sum -1\boxplus 1:
The scalar multiple 2\boxdot -1:
The additive inverse of -1, \boxminus -1:
The zero vector, \underline{0}_V:
The additive inverse of x, \boxminus x:
A square matrix A is idempotent if A^2 = A.
Let V be the vector space of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries. Let H be the set of all 2 \times 2 idempotent matrices with real entries. Is H a subspace of the vector space V?

li.p: Does H contain the zero vector of V?
H contains the zero vector of V
H does not contain the zero vector of V
Is H closed under addition?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under addition, it is sufficient to find two idempotent matrices A and B such that (A+B)^2 \ne (A+B).)
Is H closed under scalar multiplication?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under scalar multiplication, it is sufficient to find a real number r and an idempotent matrix A such that (rA)^2 \ne (rA).)
Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
You should be able to justify your answer by writing a complete, coherent, and detailed proof based on your answers to parts 1-3.
H is a subspace of V
H is not a subspace of V

p.m: \text{H contains the zero vector of V}
\text{H is not a subspace of V}

statement.p: The trace of a square n \times n matrix A = (a_{ij}) is the sum a_{11} + a_{22} + \cdots + a_{nn} of the entries on its main diagonal.
Let V be the vector space of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries.
Let H be the set of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries that have trace 0. Is H a subspace of the vector space V?

li.p: Does H contain the zero vector of V?
H contains the zero vector of V
H does not contain the zero vector of V
Is H closed under addition?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under addition, it is sufficient to find two trace zero matrices A and B such that A+B has nonzero trace.)
Is H closed under scalar multiplication?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under scalar multiplication, it is sufficient to find a real number r and a trace zero matrix A such that rA has nonzero trace.)
Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
You should be able to justify your answer by writing a complete, coherent, and detailed proof based on your answers to parts 1-3.
H is a subspace of V
H is not a subspace of V

p.m: \text{H contains the zero vector of V}

statement.p: The trace of a square n \times n matrix A = (a_{ij}) is the sum a_{11} + a_{22} + \cdots + a_{nn} of the entries on its main diagonal.
Let V be the vector space of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries. Let H be the set of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries that have trace 1. Is H a subspace of the vector space V?

li.p: Does H contain the zero vector of V?
H contains the zero vector of V
H does not contain the zero vector of V
Is H closed under addition?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under addition, it is sufficient to find two trace one matrices A and B such that A+B has trace not equal to one.)
Is H closed under scalar multiplication?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under scalar multiplication, it is sufficient to find a real number r and a trace one matrix A such that rA has trace not equal to one.)
Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
You should be able to justify your answer by writing a complete, coherent, and detailed proof based on your answers to parts 1-3.
H is a subspace of V
H is not a subspace of V

p.m: \text{H does not contain the zero vector of V}
\text{H is not a subspace of V}

statement.p: Let V be the vector space of symmetric 2\times 2 matrices and W be the subspace W=\operatorname{span} \left\{ {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 \amp -5\cr -5 \amp -3 \end{array}\right]},{\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 \amp 4\cr 4 \amp 4 \end{array}\right]} \right\} .

li.p: Find a nonzero element X in W.
Find an element Y in V that is not in W.

statement.p: Let V be the vector space P_3(\mathbb{R} of polynomials in x with degree less than 3 and W be the subspace W=\operatorname{span} \left\lbrace {5+3x+3x^{2}},{6x-5-2x^{2}} \right\rbrace .

li.p: Find a nonzero polynomial p(x) in W.
Find a polynomial q(x) in V that does not belong to W.

statement.p: If possible, write {24+8x+14x^{2}} as a linear combination of {2+x+x^{2}}, {-2-x^{2}} and {-3-x-2x^{2}}.
Let {\bf u}_4 be a vector that is not a linear combination of \left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,\right\rbrace.
Select the best statement.

li.p: We only know that span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3 \right\rbrace \subseteq span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4 \right\rbrace.
span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3\right\rbrace is a proper subset of span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4\right\rbrace.
We only know that span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4\right\rbrace\subseteq span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3\right\rbrace .

span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3\right\rbrace= span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4\right\rbrace when none of \left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,\right\rbrace is a linear combination of the others.
There is no obvious relationship between span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3\right\rbrace and span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4\right\rbrace .
span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3\right\rbrace= span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4\right\rbrace .
none of the above

static.solution: \left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3\right\rbrace is a proper subset of span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4\right\rbrace.

statement.p: Let \mathbf{u}_4 be a linear combination of \left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2, \mathbf{u}_3\right\rbrace.
Select the best statement.

li.p: There is no obvious relationship between span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3\right\rbrace and span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3,\mathbf{u}_4\right\rbrace .
We only know that span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3 \right\rbrace \subseteq span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3,\mathbf{u}_4\right\rbrace .
We only know that span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3,\mathbf{u}_4\right\rbrace\subseteq span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3\right\rbrace .
span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3\right\rbrace= span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3,\mathbf{u}_4\right\rbrace .

span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3\right\rbrace= span\left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3,\mathbf{u}_4\right\rbrace when none of \left\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3\right\rbrace is a linear combination of the others.
none of the above

statement.p: Let x, y, z be (non-zero) vectors and suppose w = -8x-4y-3z.
If z= -2x-y, then w = x+ y.
Using the calculation above, mark the statements below that must be true.

li.p: Span(x, z) = Span(w, z)
Span(w, z) = Span(x, y)
Span(w, x, y) = Span(y, z)
Span(x, y) = Span(x, y, z)
Span(w, y) = Span(x, z)

statement.p: Let \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace be a linearly independent set of vectors.
Select the best statement.

li.p: \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is never a linearly independent set of vectors.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace could be a linearly independent or linearly dependent set of vectors depending on the vectors chosen.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is always a linearly independent set of vectors.
none of the above

static.solution: \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is always a linearly independent set of vectors.

statement.p: Let {\bf u}_4 be a linear combination of \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3 }\rbrace.
Select the best statement.

li.p: \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is never a linearly independent set of vectors.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace could be a linearly dependent or linearly dependent set of vectors depending on the vectors chosen.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is a linearly dependent set of vectors unless one of \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is the zero vector.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is never a linearly dependent set of vectors.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is always a linearly independent set of vectors.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace could be a linearly dependent or linearly dependent set of vectors depending on the vector space chosen.
none of the above

static.solution:
{\bf u}_4=a_1{\bf u}_1 + a_2 {\bf u}_2 + a_3 {\bf u}_3, then
0=a_1{\bf u}_1 + a_2 {\bf u}_2 + a_3 {\bf u}_3-{\bf u}_4
"\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is never a linearly independent set of vectors."

statement.p: Assume {\bf u}_4 is not a linear combination of \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3 }\rbrace.
Select the best statement.

li.p: \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace could be a linearly independent or linearly dependent set of vectors depending on the vector space chosen.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is a linearly dependent set precisely when \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is a linearly dependent set.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is a linearly independent set of vectors unless one of \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is the zero vector.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is always a linearly dependent set of vectors.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is never a linearly dependent set of vectors.
none of the above

static.solution:
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is a linearly dependent set, then adding in {\bf u}_4 keeps it dependent.
If \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is a linearly independent set, then consider any nontrivial solution to a_1 {\bf u}_1+ a_2 {\bf u}_2 + a_3{\bf u}_3 + a_4 {\bf u}_4 = {\bf 0} If a_4=0, this gives us a nontrivial dependence relation for the independent set.
If a_4\ne 0, the equation can be solved to show {\bf u}_4 is a linear combination of \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3 }\rbrace.
\lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is a linearly dependent set precisely when \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace is a linearly dependent set.

li.p: Choose
linearly dependent
linearly independent

statement.p: If they are linearly dependent, find scalars that are not all zero such that the equation below is true. If they are linearly independent, find the only scalars that will make the equation below true.
\vec{u} + \vec{v} + \vec{w} = \vec{0}.
Are the vectors 12+4x-4x^{2}, \ 12+8x+16x^{2} and 12+6x+6x^{2} linearly independent?

li.p: choose
linearly dependent
linearly independent

statement.p: If the vectors are independent, enter zero in every answer blank since zeros are only the values that make the equation below true. If they are dependent, find numbers, not all zero, that make the equation below true. You should be able to explain and justify your answer.
Determine whether or not the following sets S of 2\times 2 matrices are linearly independent.
Let S= \left\{r, u, d, x \right\} be a set of vectors.
If x = 5 r+ 5 u+ 2 d, determine whether or not S is linearly independent.

li.p: Determine whether or not the four vectors listed above are linearly independent or linearly dependent.

statement.p: If S is dependent, enter a non-trivial linear relation below. Otherwise, enter 0's for the coefficients.
r+ u+ d+ x =0.

Find a basis \lbrace p(x), q(x) \rbrace for the vector space \lbrace f(x)\in{\mathbb P}_3[x] \mid f'(-8)=f(1) \rbrace where {\mathbb P}_3[x] is the vector space of polynomials in x with degree less than 3.
Find a basis for the vector space \lbrace A\in {\mathbb R}^{2\times 2} \mid \text{tr}(A)=0\rbrace of 2\times 2 matrices with trace 0.
B = \Biggl\lbrace,, \Biggr\rbrace.
Suppose that S_1 and S_2 are nonzero subspaces, with S_1 contained inside S_2, and suppose that dim(S_2) = 3.

(a) What are the possible dimensions of S_1?
?
1
2
3
1 or 2
1,2, or 3

(b) If S_1\neq S_2 then what are the possible dimensions of S_1?
?
1
2
3
1 or 2
1,2, or 3

static.solution:
(a) The dimension of S_1 cannot exceed the dimension of S_2 since S_1 is contained in S_2. S_1 is non-zero, and thus its dimension cannot be 0. Hence 1, 2, or 3 are the possible dimensions of S_1.
(b) If S_1 \ne S_2, then S_1 is properly contained in S_2, and the dimension of S_1 is strictly less than the dimension of S_2. Thus only 1 or 2 are possible dimensions of S_1 .

statement.p: Let \mathcal{P}_2 be the vector space of all polynomials of degree 2 or less, and let H be the subspace spanned by {13-\left(5x^{2}+20x\right)}, \ {5-\left(2x^{2}+8x\right)} and {3x^{2}+12x-7}.

li.p: What is the dimension of the subspace H?
Is \lbrace {13-\left(5x^{2}+20x\right)}, {5-\left(2x^{2}+8x\right)}, {3x^{2}+12x-7} \rbrace a basis for \mathcal{P}_2?

basis for P_2
not a basis for P_2
Be sure you can explain and justify your answer.
Give a basis for the subspace H.

statement.p: Let \mathcal{P}_2 be the vector space of all polynomials of degree 2 or less, and let H be the subspace spanned by {3x^{2}+12x+19}, \ {9x^{2}+29x+51} and {x+1}.

li.p: What is the dimension of the subspace H?
Is \lbrace {3x^{2}+12x+19}, {9x^{2}+29x+51}, {x+1} \rbrace a basis for \mathcal{P}_2?
choose
basis for P_2
not a basis for P_2
Be sure you can explain and justify your answer.
Give a basis for the subspace H.

statement.p: Let U=\spn\{{6x^{2}-7},{7x-3x^{2}}\} and W=\spn\{{3x^{3}-6x^{2}},{27x^{2}-21x-21}\} be subspaces of the vector space V=P_3(\R)\text{.}

li.p: Yes
No
What is the dimension of U+W\text{?}
What is the dimension of U\cap W\text{?}

Suppose f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}^{3} is a linear transformation such that f \left( \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -1 \\ -2 \\ -5 \end{array} \right), \quad f \left( \begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 2 \\ -3 \\ 3 \end{array} \right).Then \displaystyle{ f \left( \begin{array}{r} -6 \\ 4 \end{array} \right) = }.

Suppose f : \mathbb{R}^{12} \to \mathbb{R}^{2} is a linear transformation such that f \left( \begin{array}{c} {\vec{e}}_4 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 3 \\ -4 \end{array} \right), \quad f \left( \begin{array}{c} {\vec{e}}_7 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -5 \\ 3 \end{array} \right), \quad f \left( \begin{array}{c} {\vec{e}}_8 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -4 \\ 1 \end{array} \right).Then \displaystyle{ f ( 2 {\vec{e}}_4 + 3 {\vec{e}}_7 ) - f ( 7 {\vec{e}}_8 + 5 {\vec{e}}_7 )= }

Let V be a vector space and let {\vec{v}}_1, {\vec{v}}_2, {\vec{v}}_3 \in V. Suppose T : V \to \mathbb{R}^{2} is a linear transformation such that T({\vec{v}}_1) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -1 \\ -3 \end{array} \right), \quad T({\vec{v}}_2) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 4 \\ -4 \end{array} \right), \quad T({\vec{v}}_3) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 2 \end{array} \right).Then -3 T({\vec{v}}_1) + T(3 {\vec{v}}_2 + 6 {\vec{v}}_3) =

statement.p: Let M_{n,n}(\mathbb{R}) denote the vector space of n \times n matrices with real entries. Let f : M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}) \to M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}) be the function defined by f(A) = A^T for any A \in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}). Is f a linear transformation?

Let A = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} a_{11} \amp a_{12}\cr a_{21} \amp a_{22}\cr \end{array}\right]} and B = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} b_{11} \amp b_{12}\cr b_{21} \amp b_{22}\cr \end{array}\right]} be any two matrices in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}) and let c \in \mathbb{R}.

li.p:
Does f(A+B) = f(A) + f(B) for all A, B \in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R})?
Yes, they are equal
No, they are not equal
f(c A) = .
c(f(A)) = \Bigg( \Bigg).

Does f(c A) = c(f(A)) for all c \in \mathbb{R} and all A \in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R})?
Yes, they are equal
No, they are not equal

Is f a linear transformation?
f is a linear transformation
f is not a linear transformation

statement.p: Let f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} be defined by f(x) = {7x-9}. Is f a linear transformation?

li.p:
Does f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y) for all x,y \in \mathbb{R}?
Yes, they are equal
No, they are not equal
f(c x) = .
c(f(x)) = \Big( \Big).

Does f(cx) = c(f(x)) for all c, x \in \mathbb{R}?
Yes, they are equal
No, they are not equal

Is f a linear transformation?
f is a linear transformation
f is not a linear transformation

statement.p: Let V and W be vector spaces and let \vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2 \in V and \vec{w}_1, \vec{w}_2 \in W.

li.p: Suppose T : V \to W is a linear transformation.
Find T( 5 \vec{v}_1 - \vec{v}_2) and write your answer in terms of T(\vec{v}_1) and T(\vec{v}_2).
Suppose L : V \to W is a linear transformation such that L(\vec{v}_1) = \vec{w}_1 + \vec{w}_2 and L(\vec{v}_2) = - 8 \vec{w}_2.
Find L(4 \vec{v}_1 + 7 \vec{v}_2) in terms of \vec{w}_1 and \vec{w}_2.

statement.p: Let T:{\mathbb R}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^2 be a linear transformation that sends the vector \vec{u} =(5,2) into (2,1) and maps \vec{v}= (1,3) into (-1, 3). Use properties of a linear transformation to calculate the following.

If T maps (6, -8) to the vector \vec{y}, find \vec{y}

Let \vec{v}_1= {\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr -1 \end{array}\right]} \ \mbox{ and } \ \vec{v}_2={\left[\begin{array}{c} -2\cr -1 \end{array}\right]} . Let T:{\mathbb R}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^2 be the linear transformation satisfying T(\vec{v}_1)={\left[\begin{array}{c} 4\cr -6 \end{array}\right]} \ \mbox{ and } \ T(\vec{v}_2)={\left[\begin{array}{c} 5\cr -10 \end{array}\right]} . Find the image T \left({\left[\begin{array}{c} x\cr y\cr \end{array}\right]}\right) of an arbitrary vector {\left[\begin{array}{c} x\cr y\cr \end{array}\right]} .

find the value of \ T \left({\left[\begin{array}{c} -2\cr 0\cr 1 \end{array}\right]}\right).

(b) Find the dimension of the kernel of L:
(c) Let S be the subspace of \mathbb{R}^3 spanned by 9 e_1 and -9 e_2 - 9 e_3. Find the dimension of L(S):

solution.p: (a) Since e_1, e_2, e_3 spans \mathbb{R}^3, we get that L(\mathbb{R}^3) is spanned by L(e_1), L(e_2), L(e_3). So
and hence the dimension of the range is 2.
(b) The rank-nullity theorem implies that the dimension of the kernel is 3-2 = 1.
and it is easy to check that these two vectors are linearly independent. Therefore, the dimension of L(S) is 2.

statement.p: Let \mathcal{P}_n be the vector space of all polynomials of degree n or less in the variable x. Let D^2 : \mathcal{P}_4 \to \mathcal{P}_2 be the linear transformation that takes a polynomial to its second derivative. That is, D^2(p(x)) = p''(x) for any polynomial p(x) of degree 4 or less.

li.p: Find a basis for the kernel of D^2.
Find a basis for the image of D^2.

statement.p: Let T:P_3 \rightarrow P_3 be defined by T(ax^2+bx+c)=(2 a + b)x^2 + (2 a - 3 b + c) x - a . Find the inverse of T.

li.p: The linear transformation T_1: R^2 \rightarrow R^2 is given by
The linear transformation T_2: R^3 \rightarrow R^3 is given by
Find T_2^{-1}(x, y, z):
Using T_1 from part a, it is given that:
Find x and y.
x = , y =
Using T_2 from part b, it is given that:
Find x, y, and z.

statement.p: Let \left\lbrace \vec{e}_1, \ \vec{e}_2, \ \vec{e}_3, \ \vec{e}_4, \ \vec{e}_5, \ \vec{e}_6 \right\rbrace be the standard basis in {\mathbb R}^6. Find the length of the vector \vec{x} = -3\vec{e}_1 + 5\vec{e}_2 + 3\vec{e}_3 + 4\vec{e}_4 + 3\vec{e}_5 - 5\vec{e}_6.
Find the norm of \vec{x} and the unit vector \vec{u} in the direction of \vec{x} if \displaystyle{ \vec{x} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr -5\cr -3\cr 1 \end{array}\right]}. }
Given that \len{\xx}=4, \len{\yy}=3\text{,} and \xx\dotp\yy=1\text{,} compute (4\xx-3\yy)\dotp (\xx+5\yy)\text{.}

hint.p: Use properties of the dot product to expand and simplify.

solution.p: Note that the distributive property, together with symmetry, let us handle this dot product using what is essentially FOIL:

statement.p: Let { \mathbf{u}_1, \mathbf{u}_2, \mathbf{u}_3 } be an orthonormal basis for an inner product space V. If
is so that \|\mathbf{v}\| = 80, \mathbf{v} is orthogonal to \mathbf{u}_3, and \langle \mathbf{v},\mathbf{u}_2 \rangle = -80, find the possible values for a, b, and c.

solution.p: Solution: One checks by direct computation that

statement.p: Find two linearly independent vectors perpendicular to the vector \vec{v}= {\left[\begin{array}{c} -8\cr -1\cr 5 \end{array}\right]}.

Let \mathbf{v}_1 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}2\\5\\0\\4\\0\\0\\\end{array}\right]}, \mathbf{v}_2 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}-3\\0\\2\\-4\\0\\-5\\\end{array}\right]}, \text{ and } \mathbf{v}_3 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}-3\\0\\0\\-5\\5\\-5\\\end{array}\right]}.
Use the Gram-Schmidt procedure to produce an orthogonal set with the same span.

Let \mathbf{v}_1 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}3\\0\\2\\0\\2\\-1\\\end{array}\right]}, \mathbf{v}_2 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}3\\-4\\1\\0\\4\\0\\\end{array}\right]}, \text{ and } \mathbf{v}_3 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}3\\0\\3\\-5\\2\\0\\\end{array}\right]}.
Use the Gram-Schmidt procedure to produce an orthogonal set with the same span.

Let \mathbf{v}_1 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}0\\0\\5\\3\\4\\0\\\end{array}\right]}, \mathbf{v}_2 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\0\\2\\0\\2\\15\\\end{array}\right]}, \text{ and } \mathbf{v}_3 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}2\\5\\5\\0\\3\\0\\\end{array}\right]}.
Use the Gram-Schmidt procedure to produce an orthogonal set with the same span.
\mathbf{u}_1 =, \mathbf{u}_2 =, \mathbf{u}_3 =
Find orthonormal bases of the kernel and image of A.

Given v=\begin{bmatrix}{{\frac{33}{4}}}\\ {{\frac{77}{6}}}\\ {-{\frac{367}{12}}}\end{bmatrix}, find the coordinates for v in the subspace W spanned by u_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}-3\\ -2\\ -1\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{ and } \quad u_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ -5\\ 16\end{bmatrix}.
Note that u_{1} and u_{2} are orthogonal.
Let W be the set of all vectors {\left[\begin{array}{c} x\cr y\cr x+y\cr \end{array}\right]} with x and y real. Find a vector whose span is W^{\perp}.

Let \vec{u} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -2\cr 7\cr 3\cr 4 \end{array}\right]} and \vec{v} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\cr -3\cr 3\cr -3 \end{array}\right]}, and let W the subspace of {\mathbb R}^4 spanned by \vec{u} and \vec{v}. Find a basis of W^{\perp}, the orthogonal complement of W in \mathbb{R}^4.
Let y=\begin{bmatrix}5\\ 5\\ 7\end{bmatrix}, u_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 4\\ -2\end{bmatrix}, and u_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}-4\\ 1\\ -2\end{bmatrix}.
Compute the distance d from y to the plane in {\mathbb R}^3 spanned by u_{1} and u_{2}.

Given \vec{v}={\left[\begin{array}{c} -5\cr -2\cr 7\cr -9 \end{array}\right]}, find the closest point to \vec{v} in the subspace W spanned by {\left[\begin{array}{c} 4\cr -4\cr -6\cr 1 \end{array}\right]} and {\left[\begin{array}{c} 6\cr -3\cr -4\cr -60 \end{array}\right]}.

Find the orthogonal projection of \vec{v}={\left[\begin{array}{c} 9\cr 16\cr 7 \end{array}\right]} onto the subspace W of {\mathbb R}^3 spanned by {\left[\begin{array}{c} 5\cr 2\cr -2 \end{array}\right]} and {\left[\begin{array}{c} 0\cr 7\cr 7 \end{array}\right]}.
